title: On the complexity of finding large odd induced subgraphs and odd coloringsWork supported by French projects DEMOGRAPH (ANR-16-CE40-0028), ESIGMA (ANR-17-CE23-0010), and ELIT (ANR-20-CE48-0008-01), the program “Exploration Japon 2017” of the French embassy in Japan, and the JSPS KAKENHI grant number JP18K11157. An extended abstract of this article appeared in the Proceedings of the 46th International Workshop on Graph-Theoretic Concepts in Computer Science (WG), volume 12301 of LNCS, pages 67-79, held online, June 2020. This article is permanently available at https://arxiv.org/abs/2002.06078.

sections.tight bounds:
In this section we provide two tight bounds concerning odd induced subgraphs and odd colorings. Namely, we first provide in Theorem 5.1 a tight upper bound on the odd chromatic number in terms of tree-width, and then we provide in Theorem 5.2 a tight lower bound on the size of a maximum odd induced subgraph for graphs that admit a join. For every graph G𝐺G with all components of even order we have that χ𝗈𝖽𝖽​(G)≤𝗍𝗐​(G)+1subscript𝜒𝗈𝖽𝖽𝐺𝗍𝗐𝐺1\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq{\sf tw}(G)+1, and this bound is tight. Scott proved [42, Corollary 3] that every graph G𝐺G with all components of even order admits a vertex partition such that every vertex
class induces a tree with all degrees odd. Consider such a vertex partition, and let G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} be the graph obtained from G𝐺G by contracting each of the trees to a single vertex. Since G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is a minor of G𝐺G, we have that 𝗍𝗐​(G′)≤𝗍𝗐​(G)𝗍𝗐superscript𝐺′𝗍𝗐𝐺{\sf tw}(G^{\prime})\leq{\sf tw}(G). Now note that every proper vertex coloring of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} using q𝑞q colors can be lifted to a partition of V​(G)𝑉𝐺V(G) into q𝑞q odd induced subgraphs (in fact, odd induced forests). Indeed, with every color i𝑖i of a proper q𝑞q-coloring of V​(G′)𝑉superscript𝐺′V(G^{\prime}) we associate an induced forest of G𝐺G defined by the union of the trees whose corresponding vertex in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime} is colored i𝑖i; see Fig 6 for an example. Therefore, where we have used the well-known fact that the chromatic number of a graph is at most its tree-width plus one . To see that this bound it tight, consider a subdivided clique Knsuperscriptsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ }, that is, the graph obtained from a clique on n𝑛n vertices, with n≡0,3(mod4)𝑛0annotated3pmod4n\equiv 0,3\pmod{4}, by subdividing every edge once; see Fig. 7 for an example. Since no pair of original vertices of the clique can get the same color, we have that χ𝗈𝖽𝖽​(Kn)=n=𝗍𝗐​(Kn)+1subscript𝜒𝗈𝖽𝖽superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑛𝑛𝗍𝗐superscriptsubscript𝐾𝑛1\chi_{{\sf odd}}(K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ })=n={\sf tw}(K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ })+1. Let us mention some consequences of Theorem 5.1. Hou et al. 7 define the following parameter. Let 𝒢ksubscript𝒢𝑘\mathcal{G}_{k} be the set of all graphs of treewidth at most k𝑘k without isolated vertices, and let ck=minG∈𝒢k⁡𝗆𝗈𝗌​(G)|V​(G)|subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝐺subscript𝒢𝑘𝗆𝗈𝗌𝐺𝑉𝐺c_{k}=\min_{G\in\mathcal{G}_{k}}\frac{{\sf mos}(G)}{|V(G)|}. In 7 the authors prove that c2=2/5subscript𝑐225c_{2}=2/5 and say that the best general lower bound is ck≥12​k+2subscript𝑐𝑘12𝑘2c_{k}\geq\frac{1}{2k+2}, which follows from a result of Scott . As an immediate corollary of Theorem 5.1 it follows that ck≥1k+1subscript𝑐𝑘1𝑘1c_{k}\geq\frac{1}{k+1}, which improves the lower bound by a factor two. As it is known 7 that, for k∈𝑘delimited-[]4k\in, ck≤2k+3subscript𝑐𝑘2𝑘3c_{k}\leq\frac{2}{k+3}, our lower bound implies that 1/4≤c3≤1/314subscript𝑐3131/4\leq c_{3}\leq 1/3 and 1/5≤c4≤2/715subscript𝑐4271/5\leq c_{4}\leq 2/7. We now provide a lower bound on 𝗆𝗈𝗌​(G)𝗆𝗈𝗌𝐺{\sf mos}(G) for every graph that admits a join. For every n𝑛n-vertex graph G𝐺G that admits a join we have and this bound is tight even for cographs. Let V1,V2⊆V​(G)subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2𝑉𝐺V_{1},V_{2}\subseteq V(G) define a join of G𝐺G. We proceed to define a coloring c:V​(G)→:𝑐→𝑉𝐺delimited-[]3c:V(G)\to such that, for some i∈𝑖delimited-[]3i\in, G​[c−1​(i)]𝐺delimited-[]superscript𝑐1𝑖G[c^{-1}(i)] is an odd subgraph with the claimed order. We distinguish three cases according to the parities of n𝑛n, |V1|subscript𝑉1|V_{1}|, and |V2|subscript𝑉2|V_{2}|. Case 1: n𝑛n is even and both |V1|,|V2|subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2|V_{1}|,|V_{2}| are odd. Gallai proved (see ) that the vertex set of every graph G𝐺G can be partitioned into two sets A,B𝐴𝐵A,B such that G​[A]𝐺delimited-[]𝐴G[A] is odd and G​[B]𝐺delimited-[]𝐵G[B] is even. We apply this result to both G​[V1]𝐺delimited-[]subscript𝑉1G[V_{1}] and G​[V2]𝐺delimited-[]subscript𝑉2G[V_{2}], yielding four sets V1𝖾,V1𝗈,V2𝖾,V2𝗈superscriptsubscript𝑉1𝖾superscriptsubscript𝑉1𝗈superscriptsubscript𝑉2𝖾superscriptsubscript𝑉2𝗈V_{1}^{{\sf e}},V_{1}^{{\sf o}},V_{2}^{{\sf e}},V_{2}^{{\sf o}} such that, for i∈𝑖delimited-[]2i\in, Vi=Vi𝖾⊎Vi𝗈subscript𝑉𝑖⊎superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝖾superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝗈V_{i}=V_{i}^{{\sf e}}\uplus V_{i}^{{\sf o}}, G​[Vi𝖾]𝐺delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝖾G[V_{i}^{{\sf e}}] is even, and G​[Vi𝗈]𝐺delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝗈G[V_{i}^{{\sf o}}] is odd. For i∈𝑖delimited-[]2i\in, the fact that G​[Vi𝗈]𝐺delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝗈G[V_{i}^{{\sf o}}] is odd implies that |Vi𝗈|superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝗈|V_{i}^{{\sf o}}| is even, which in turn implies that |Vi𝖾|superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝖾|V_{i}^{{\sf e}}| is odd since, by assumption, |Vi𝖾|+|Vi𝗈|=|Vi|superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝖾superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝗈subscript𝑉𝑖|V_{i}^{{\sf e}}|+|V_{i}^{{\sf o}}|=|V_{i}| is odd. We define c−1​(1)=V1𝖾∪V2𝖾superscript𝑐11superscriptsubscript𝑉1𝖾superscriptsubscript𝑉2𝖾c^{-1}(1)=V_{1}^{{\sf e}}\cup V_{2}^{{\sf e}}, c−1​(2)=V1𝗈∪V2𝗈superscript𝑐12superscriptsubscript𝑉1𝗈superscriptsubscript𝑉2𝗈c^{-1}(2)=V_{1}^{{\sf o}}\cup V_{2}^{{\sf o}}, and c−1​(3)=∅superscript𝑐13c^{-1}(3)=\emptyset. Since V1,V2≠∅subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2V_{1},V_{2}\neq\emptyset as they define a join of G𝐺G, and both |V1|subscript𝑉1|V_{1}| and |V2|subscript𝑉2|V_{2}| are odd, it follows that, for i∈𝑖delimited-[]2i\in, Vi𝖾≠∅superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖𝖾V_{i}^{{\sf e}}\neq\emptyset. This implies that both G​[c−1​(1)]𝐺delimited-[]superscript𝑐11G[c^{-1}(1)] and G​[c−1​(2)]𝐺delimited-[]superscript𝑐12G[c^{-1}(2)] are odd, and therefore one of them has order at least n/2𝑛2n/2. Case 2: n𝑛n is even and both |V1|,|V2|subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2|V_{1}|,|V_{2}| are even. Let v1∈V1subscript𝑣1subscript𝑉1v_{1}\in V_{1} and v2∈V2subscript𝑣2subscript𝑉2v_{2}\in V_{2} be two arbitrary vertices. We define c​(v1)=c​(v2)=3𝑐subscript𝑣1𝑐subscript𝑣23c(v_{1})=c(v_{2})=3 and we apply Case 1 above to the graph G−{v1,v2}𝐺subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2G-\{v_{1},v_{2}\} with join given by V1∖{v1}subscript𝑉1subscript𝑣1V_{1}\setminus\{v_{1}\} and V2∖{v2}subscript𝑉2subscript𝑣2V_{2}\setminus\{v_{2}\}, obtaining two odd induced subgraphs of G𝐺G colored 1 and 2, one of which has order at least (n−2)/2𝑛22(n-2)/2. Note that G​[c−1​(3)]𝐺delimited-[]superscript𝑐13G[c^{-1}(3)] is also an odd subgraph (an edge). Case 3: n𝑛n is odd. Assume without loss of generality that |V1|subscript𝑉1|V_{1}| is even and |V2|subscript𝑉2|V_{2}| is odd, and let v1∈V1subscript𝑣1subscript𝑉1v_{1}\in V_{1} be an arbitrary vertex. We apply again Case 1 to the graph G−{v1}𝐺subscript𝑣1G-\{v_{1}\} with join given by V1∖{v1}subscript𝑉1subscript𝑣1V_{1}\setminus\{v_{1}\} and V2subscript𝑉2V_{2}, obtaining two odd induced subgraphs of G𝐺G, one of which has order at least (n−1)/2𝑛12(n-1)/2. Note that since n𝑛n is odd, in this case χ𝗈𝖽𝖽​(G)subscript𝜒𝗈𝖽𝖽𝐺\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G) is not defined. Summarizing, we have proved that if n𝑛n is even, then 𝗆𝗈𝗌​(G)≥n−22𝗆𝗈𝗌𝐺𝑛22{\sf mos}(G)\geq\frac{n-2}{2}, and that if n𝑛n is odd, then 𝗆𝗈𝗌​(G)≥n−12𝗆𝗈𝗌𝐺𝑛12{\sf mos}(G)\geq\frac{n-1}{2}. Taking into account that an odd subgraph must have even order, both cases imply that, for every n𝑛n, 𝗆𝗈𝗌​(G)≥2⋅⌈n−24⌉𝗆𝗈𝗌𝐺⋅2𝑛24{\sf mos}(G)\geq 2\cdot\left\lceil\frac{n-2}{4}\right\rceil. Let us now see that this bound is tight for both even and odd values of n𝑛n. For even n𝑛n, consider the tripartite graph K2,2,2subscript𝐾222K_{2,2,2}. It can be checked that this graph contains none of K4subscript𝐾4K_{4}, K1,3subscript𝐾13K_{1,3}, and 2​K22subscript𝐾22K_{2} (which are the only odd subgraphs on four vertices) as an induced subgraph, and therefore 𝗆𝗈𝗌​(K2,2,2)=2=2⋅⌈6−24⌉𝗆𝗈𝗌subscript𝐾2222⋅2624{\sf mos}(K_{2,2,2})=2=2\cdot\left\lceil\frac{6-2}{4}\right\rceil. Finally, for odd n𝑛n, consider C5+superscriptsubscript𝐶5C_{5}^{+}, that is, the graph obtained from C5subscript𝐶5C_{5} by adding (any) two vertex-disjoint chords. Again, it can be checked that this graph contains none of K4subscript𝐾4K_{4}, K1,3subscript𝐾13K_{1,3}, and 2​K22subscript𝐾22K_{2} as an induced subgraph, and therefore 𝗆𝗈𝗌​(C5+)=2=2⋅⌈5−24⌉𝗆𝗈𝗌superscriptsubscript𝐶52⋅2524{\sf mos}(C_{5}^{+})=2=2\cdot\left\lceil\frac{5-2}{4}\right\rceil.
Note that both K2,2,2subscript𝐾222K_{2,2,2} and C5+superscriptsubscript𝐶5C_{5}^{+} are cographs; see Fig. 8. Determining a tight lower bound for cographs that are not necessarily connected remains open. The proof of Cases 1 and 2 of Theorem 5.1 together with the fact that χ𝗈𝖽𝖽​(K2,2,2)=3subscript𝜒𝗈𝖽𝖽subscript𝐾2223\chi_{{\sf odd}}(K_{2,2,2})=3 (since 𝗆𝗈𝗌​(K2,2,2)=2𝗆𝗈𝗌subscript𝐾2222{\sf mos}(K_{2,2,2})=2) yield the following corollary. Let G𝐺G be a cograph with every connected component of even order. Then χ𝗈𝖽𝖽​(G)≤3subscript𝜒𝗈𝖽𝖽𝐺3\chi_{{\sf odd}}(G)\leq 3. Moreover, this bound is tight. Note that cographs can be equivalently defined as P4subscript𝑃4P_{4}-free graphs. It is interesting to note that, in contrast to Corollary 1, P5subscript𝑃5P_{5}-free graphs have unbounded odd chromatic number. Indeed, let Hnsubscript𝐻𝑛H_{n} be the graph obtained from the subdivided clique Knsuperscriptsubscript𝐾𝑛K_{n}^{\,\begin{picture}(-1.0,1.0)(-1.0,-2.5)\circle*{2.0}\end{picture}\ }, with n≡0,3(mod4)𝑛0annotated3pmod4n\equiv 0,3\pmod{4}, by adding an edge between each pair of original vertices of the clique. It can be checked that χ𝗈𝖽𝖽​(Hn)≥nsubscript𝜒𝗈𝖽𝖽subscript𝐻𝑛𝑛\chi_{{\sf odd}}(H_{n})\geq n and, in fact, the proof of Theorem 3.2 implies that χ𝗈𝖽𝖽​(Hn)=nsubscript𝜒𝗈𝖽𝖽subscript𝐻𝑛𝑛\chi_{{\sf odd}}(H_{n})=n. Note that Hnsubscript𝐻𝑛H_{n} is a split graph, hence split graphs have unbounded odd chromatic number.
